messages.message: Hey Brian. Looks like we passed each others as you started at Schwab and I was on my way out. One of the CapTech recruiters would like to talk to you about a job in Denver. Are you interested in talking to her? you can see more about CapTech at: https://www.captechconsulting.com/
specifically we are looking for java and mobile developers

Yeah I was on my way out too! And I just started. My manager was biased and thought that I thought the project was boring. I never said it was boring but it was! Haha. I would love to entertain the idea of moving to Denver. My wife hates the heat here and needs to escape.
Thank you for thinking of me.

Just curious who was your manager and what was the project? 

I'll connect you to the recruiter through LinkedIn.

Access management team was trying to create a new department and more rules. The project manager was a total frog too. She asked me if I did my HR training yet like 20 times. The PM acted like my boss instead of my partner. I should have stood up for myself. CS is really in to corporate titles like who is allowed to talk to who.

Yes they are. I was there a long time and was well connected and had the title, but still couldn't take it. The PMs there over step their role way too often. 

CapTech is much better! Good luck and let me know if you have any questions.
I guess these days it is easier to lay someone off than train them properly. Might as well hire Indians.
Everyone at Schwab should read this: http://www.cio.com/article/3200445/it-strategy/12-best-practices-it-should-avoid-at-all-costs.html
No kidding. I use them a lot for my anti-patterns. That article just gave me a few more. I'm going to have to document them all in a blog or something!
I like the part about the department chargebacks.
Yea that was one that I'll add to my list.
I thought of a better way to track employee progress but it will take my entire lifetime​ to prove out.

It starts here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YMdIgGOYKhs The foundation of knowledge of labor economics. My theory is surplus labor can be measured accurately by the employees own assessment of what they have learned over the course of a years work.
